comments.commentBody: I wish I could say this event surprises me.  I worked for the federal government as a research scientist for 20 years and learned that, at the very least, FDA, USDA-ARS, APHIS, EPA, USGS, and DOE are internally notorious for censoring science.   Federal scientists do not have tenure or academic freedom in the same way academic scientists do, and there is often a political agenda for certain kinds of data.  Scientists have been fired for drifting into the realm of “sensitive topics” in the natural course of pursuing their assigned scientific quarry.  Going off-message or off-topic is not tolerated well.  Labs that tend to produce disappointing data (by that I mean, the data does not support the political agenda) are often placed on closure lists when budgets are cut.  In the interest of stewarding taxpayer resources (funds used to pay for research) and protecting public safety (consequences of not knowing the truth), there should be a firewall between federal scientists and politicians that prevents political censorship.  This case also demonstrates that federal scientists need some form of academic freedom and whistleblower protection from their own line management.

Why are people so shocked? The DOD has monitored the Email traffic of their workers for years. They even have sophisticated computer software to monitor the content of the millions of documents for unflattering statements about things like waste, mismanagement and inappropriate behavior of bosses. They front it as just to protect secrets, but it's amazing how much non-secret information gets back to the management. If anything, the FDA is probably just catching up. The government is going to be monitoring their workers more and more as they have an awful lot of questionable and unprofessional matters going on. The paranoia of federal managers highlights a problem that has been building for a long time....When you constantly promote poorly skilled managers from inside, they eventually become a big productivity black hole results in a lot of finger pointing.

I watched the FDA kill a company that made a thermal imaging device that wasn't promoted as an alternative to mammography, but a pre-screen. You use the non-ionizing device to see it it might be worth subjecting the patient to the tissue-damaging screen, get it? But no, the big money invested in the installed base of technology would not hear of it. So women are being subjected to ionizing radiation on a scale that is unnecessary.

The company (CTI) is dead. But you can buy the copycat thing they cooked up in India! (I guess you'll have to travel there to use it, too).

THANK YOU hardly seems adequate for what these scientists have done. They are true heroes who are willing to demonstrate that which is sorely lacking in our country- ethical behavior. For what it is worth, thank you for sacrificing your careers, family, and well being for the American people.

Propoganda: "spying"

The word "spying" has a clear negative connotation, an implication that the FDA did something illicit or even illegal. If these computers were theirs, then they were entirely within their rights to monitor all uses including "personal" communications.

This of course doesn't speak to the larger issues raised in the article but simply points out the inappropriate (my opinion) and common virtually subliminal imposition by the press in general of its views on its readers.

The FDA is a joke, rubber-stamping what industry presents them.

Now, heads should roll. Shake up an inept agency!
"1984" is here.

Dear FDA,

Perhaps the idiots at your agency who cooked up this despicable scheme should consider moving to countries that do not have extradition agreements with the US. It seems, however, that they're too incompetent to even pull that one off. With that level of stupidity, it is really no wonder that those scientists wanted to blow the whistle. Those scientists are my heroes!

" ... outside medical researchers and journalists thought to be working together to put out negative and “defamatory” information about the agency ... "

Notice they never said the information WASN'T TRUE ... !!!

Why should "the clever folks who initiated and monitored this eases dropping"  be publicly identified and lose their jobs?  I think the scientists who were so stupid to use the FDA to send emails to their sources in the House should be identified and fired!  These guys are supposed to scientists and have a little bit of intelligence!  If you are going to do this kind of activity go get yourself an I-phone and communicate outside of work.  When you are at work, we are paying you to do the government's work!  Were any of them forced to lie or cheat in their work?  or jeopardize the safety of the American Public?  Why don't they just file a case?  No their House Republican bosses want them to dig up dirt so that they can further cut FDA's budget!  That is what is happening here!

this is classic. the leakers mad at the leakers. unbelievable. only a nation of public school graduates could by into this whole thang.
suibne

Particularly Bozoesque: The FDA administrators went to the IG for permission to do this. Permission denied, they did it anyway! Why ask if you're going to do it anyway? Just part of a pattern of BAD decision making on the part of a hierarchy that's reached the stage where they believe themselves to be the absolute deciders of what is/is not appropriate for others to do with information.
Very suspicious when reportedly a prominent FDA executive goes to work for the company that markets Aspartame just after Aspartame is approved - in spite of adverse test results.
Well isn't the timing of this just perfect! As if we needed another reason to demand justice for Assange. http://kellietranter.com/2012/07/to-sin-by-silence-when-they-should-prot...
When the companies survival depends upon bowing to the government/political/regulatory class, of course they pay tribute in what every from the real rulers demand.

If these scientists were trying to save me and my loved ones from excessive doses of radiation from mammograms and colonoscopies then they are heroes and should be protected under legislation that protects whistle blowers.  I would love some more information please!   Do I need to be afraid to get a mammogram?  Should I stop hounding my parents to get colonoscopies?  How can I trust any of these tests anymore?  It makes me not want to go in for the routine screenings.

I wonder how many of the commenters who think the FDA is "in the pocket" of the drug companies has ever worked in the pharmaceutical industry.
I've spent almost 20 years, now, working in pharmaceutical product development, and I certainly haven't noticed anything that smells of conspiracy. Unfortunately, it would take a book to describe the complexity of the FDA's relationship with industry. The short version, to me, is that FDA staff follows the rules; and the rules are published and public. If the rule says they should allow something, they do; if the rule says they shouldn't, they don't. Even if they don't like the general idea, they only go with the rules (and laws) they have.

I missed the first story, I guess, when it happened, but it would make me pretty angry if I learned that someone from the FDA was leaking my confidential documents to third parties. It's one thing to be a whisteblower when you see illegal activity, but this sounds to me more like scientists with a difference of opinion not winning the argument inside the FDA, trying to re-open the debate by going outside the agency.

How would you feel if you found out that someone in the IRS had sent copies of your tax return to congressional offices, because they thought that the data in your tax return was useful to them to make a point?

What privacy and rights are we discussing?  Increasingly intrusive and uninvited are the "wares" being developed and unleashed, so we have to wonder who is watching the watchers?  And the cycle continues as the FDA has been neglectful on both sides of the coin to make money and protect their discriminant behavior.  Prior to approving many harmful devices and medications, they denied approval for simple remedies, e.g. antibiotics for ulcers to maintain the influx of medications on the market that were later downgraded for other uses.  The signature on FDA operating permissions is where the inquiry should begin and competition be promoted.

Unfortunately the laws on the books only work in the most grotesque and extreme cases. I have personal experience, all negative, in the area.
The whistleblower laws are often enforced at the discretion of a US attorney, and I don't think that the people in that office are willing to protect those who blow the whistle on powerful interests. Just consider if you will the actions of Alberto Gonzalez in relation to the Bush era war crimes. Or Eric Holder and his blindness to those same issues under the 'look forward not back' policy of the current administration.
I am suggesting that the law recognize a new crime - solicitation to commit scientific fraud. Including for instance elements of the laws on conspiracy and perjury but with a mandate to investigate and report the results of all investigations periodically in public.

Confidential information, properly classifed,  is just that, and certain internal surveillance of email is justified . But it sounds like they got carried away, which makes one wonder if  some in the FDA believed their medical review practices could not stand on their own merit, or were just unwilling to defend them. Or simply wanted to avoid the headaches of additional scrutiny.These things are not simple though.

You're a little late to be scandalized. Career employees and scientists were replaced by employees from industry during the early part of the last decade. Management of numerous federal agencies were controlled by new industry officials whose job was to enforce regulations they were ideologically opposed to. Guess what happened.

One of the GOP goals is to eliminate government agencies like the FDA and Environmental Protection agencies, since it is thought by that group that government regulation impedes the activities of business and it is better for business to make their products available to the public as quickly as possible.

actually, there is another solution, one which makes even more sense: why not build a permanent olympics site, one to which the games can return year after year?

wasting all this money, every four years, is a scandal. sure it's 'prestigious' to host the games, but wouldn't it be better for cities to invest in the real infrastructure they need day in and day out. or in the futures of their children- schools, day care centers, food banks?

and one site could be maintained through corporate sponsors or some such, like all our sports stadiums etc.

personally i'd have no problem if the olympics disappeared forever. the only beneficiaries are a couple hundred athletes and the big corporations that shill their soft drinks and fast food as 'official sponsors'. ugh.
Leapy - When you are visiting Walmart you best be ON YOUR TOES.

So sorry, John, but even looking in both directions, I'm not catching your meaning....Walmart?

I'm pleased, however, to see you finally get recognition in the grid, even if in association with a cougar.
Leapy - I would tell you but it would never get past the emus.  Just Google Walamrt and toe and see what you get.

The Philadelphia Story was remade as High Society in 1956, starring Bing Crosby, Grace Kelly and Louis Armstrong, as well as Frank Sinatra and the recently puzzled Celeste Holm as his plucky co-reporter. Lots of great music. The TRUE LOVE was ASSAILboat that Dexter Haven named in honour of his temporarily divorced wife, Tracy Lord.

Yes, I still have the soundtrack.

"True Love" is a nice ballad, but i really like "That's Jazz!" with Crosby & Armstrong. There's the movie version:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K4UWfPPh-OA

and a 'better' version from The Edsel Show:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tHc99OB0Rz8

I wonder whether most Americans (especially on the Right) even know where Sweden is?  But why take an "extreme" example of a stronger public sector and better economic performance. Even Canada has a larger public sector and has been doing better than the USA for at least the past 5 years. So to Australia, Denmark, Finland, et al. That's just considering "growth." When it comes to economic opportunity, equality, and fairness -- admittedly not concepts popular among the Plutocrats, the USA is now closer to Latin America than Europe.
Sweden is too cold in the winter, and I don't speak Swedish.  Other than that, it's a great place.

So it is all about sawing off a difference between more taxes and spending less.
What is missing is the understanding that a profound shift that has occurred in some people's thinking.
Guess what - they no longer believe that meeting half-way in Washington is the best solution.
You may disagree with them and you may consider them insane, but they are not going away. And even worse... they represent a significant number of Americans.
So.. we can all moan and bellyache about an inability to meet in the middle... but we had better get used to it... business as usual is staring to dry up... going along to get along is disappearing.
Oh yeah... part deux... I am pretty sure none of them wants to live in Sweden.

I agree with much of your comment, except for the term 'bad doctors'. You are reinforcing the law industry notion that only 'bad doctors' get sued. Neurosurgeons across the board in NY State are sued on the average of once every two years. Apparently we don't have a single 'good' neurosurgeon in NY?
But the doctor does not have to be bad or in any way at fault to be the scapegoat.

True, some good doctors get sued, and they did nothing wrong. That is not a profitable way to practice law.

There are enough genuine errors out there. There are bad doctors out there. The others do cover for them. Finding someone willing to testify to what everyone knows is a big challenge. That is the best thing about hospitals without coverage: they are motivated to stand aside and not cover up using insurance money and lawyers to protect doctors who hurt patients.

There are not bad doctors? They are people, and some people disappoint. When doctors disappoint they can do horrible damage. When others cover for them, that is complicit. It needs to stop.

Perhaps some genuine peer review system would be better than lawsuits. Doctors have not as a profession made adequate efforts to do that. That is also a big part of the malpractice crisis. What doctors won't do among their own, the courts impose on them; and they don't like it.

What happens in such situations is that someone who does have coverage must pay, such as the individual doctors or an action directly against the State. Plaintiffs look for deep pockets as step one in a law suit. I know, I've done such work. Being judgment proof is a workable defense. It goes well with a willingness to shift blame and name names.

Actually, this is not all bad. Bad doctors are covered for, and the State gets away with failures that are grotesque. Blow the whistle on them. We'll all be better for it.

This is not necessarily a bad thing at all.
